Message.Title: Toahiba Excite Write hands-on: High-resolution beauty and Tegra 4 brains
Message.Msg: The Samsung Galaxy Note revived the stylus as an incredibly relevant piece of tech a few years back, and since then, other companies have tried to revive it for themselves. This new Toshiba tablet centres around a beautiful stylus, and an even better looking screen. The beautifully rhymey Excite Write from Toshiba is a 10.1-inch, Tegra 4-powered tablet with a beautiful 2560 x 1600 screen resolution and an incredibly responsive stylus. The Write is running Android 4.2, packs in 2GB of RAM, 32GB of internal storage, 8-megapixel rear-facing camera, micro-HDMI for video out and a micro-SD slot for expandable storage. The Write also backs Harman Kardon stereo speakers with a new microphone set-up that Toshiba is calling DTS Premium Voice Pro for better audio interactivity and VOIP. The Excite Write is a premium tablet at a really reasonable price, coming in at $US599 (Australian prices coming soon). The incredible 2560×1600 screen resolution makes the Xcite Write one of the highest resolution tablets out on the market today, and it makes everything look fabulous. The colours you get on the Write are simply incredible. To top it off, the screen is protected by Corning Gorilla Glass 2, which is more than welcome on our beloved gadgets. Flip the Write over and you’ll find a bright dimpled silver aluminium exterior which — when combined with premium speakers, a high resolution screen and top-quality specs — actually serves to make the whole thing pretty heavy to lug around. The Excite Write isn’t exactly unwieldy, but it’s probably going to strain your arm if you use it for a prolonged period of time. The stylus is great thanks to 1024 points of touch on the digitiser, and with a new suite of optical recognition software from Toshiba, this is a tablet for people who love to take notes. SOURCE: Gizmodo gizmodoDOTcomDOTau/2013/06/toshiba-excite-write-australian-hands-on-high-res-beauty-and-tegra-4-brains/

Message.Title: "AMD has console gaming in its pocket, but can it squeeze out Nvidia on the PC?"
Message.Msg: "AMD has console gaming in its pocket, but can it squeeze out Nvidia on the PC?" "AMD is in a very interesting position this year. Not only is it pushing the envelope with server, desktop, and mobile APUs, but it also has the console market on lock down. This week at the Computex Taipei expo, AMD doubled down on its “Unified Gaming Strategy,” and promises to work directly with game developers to make PC ports of console games easier going forward." ... "Everyone seems to be benefiting except Nvidia here. The real worry with AMD’s push for unified gaming is that games developers might shirk Nvidia optimizations. If it’s relatively simple to get Xbox One games up and running on PCs with AMD graphics, publishers might not see the need to spend the additional cash to optimize for Nvidia cards. This could be a huge hassle for the majority of PC gamers with existing Nvidia cards, but it would be even worse for Nvidia itself. While AMD has been lagging well behind lately, this PC-console strategy could help it leapfrog its competitors in a meaningful way." Source: Extremetech

Message.Title: NVIDIA Shield Australian Hands-On: The Best Portable Gaming Console You Can't Buy
Message.Msg: "When NVIDIA showed off the Android-powered Shield gaming console at CES this year, it was locked away under glass. In the meantime, pre-orders of the device have exploded while NVIDIA tweak the final product...." kotakuDOTcomDOTau/2013/06/nvidia-shield-australian-hands-on-the-best-portable-gaming-console-you-cant-buy/

Topic.Title: "AMD has console gaming in its pocket, but can it squeeze out Nvidia on the PC?"

Message.Msg: AMD walks a fine line with that strategy. Do you think that Sony and MSFT want their partners to help developers port games out of their controlled and profitable console ecosystems? They do not. Consider how easy it would be for MSFT to run the Xbox on a streamlined version of Windows, and yet that they haven't done that. Even the new Xbox essentially runs two parallel OS. Of course, that helps maintain the wall. It is a great opportunity for AMD, but a VERY risky one. AMD needs MSFT and SNE far more than the reverse is true.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA Shield Australian Hands-On: The Best Portable Gaming Console You Can't Buy

Topic.Title: "AMD has console gaming in its pocket, but can it squeeze out Nvidia on the PC?"

Message.Msg: The game developers are the ones in charge when it comes to writing games. Games developers want to sell you a copy for your Xbox One, PS4 and your PC. Games developers would always prefer to sell you 3 copies of the same game but the Cell technology made porting games from consoles to PCs difficult and the reverse, porting from the PC to game consoles. Microsoft, Sony, AMD and Game developers all contributed to the development of the custom APU SoC in the Xbox One and the PS4. According to Microsoft HSA or hUMA was what developers wanted most and HSA will be in the new Xbox One and PS4. Does Nvidia have the ability to implement HSA with hUMA across the GPU and CPU? This is what you need to think about, Can a game written with hUMA run on an Intel CPU and an Nvidia GPU with hUMA ? The answer today is NO. hUMA already happening with the blessing of Microsoft, Sony, AMD and Game Developers. And Nvidia can't touch hUMA with just a GPU. imho

Message.Title: Analysts on Intel: Lazard ponders tablet upside, Sterne Agee ponders cannibalization
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Barrons just in Lazard: ""We believe we are beginning to see the “fruits of Intel’s efforts” at this point. While there has been market discussion for some time in terms of Intel’s opportunity in tablets, we think these recent design wins represent a significant accomplishment in gaining traction with Tier-1 customers. Intel has traditionally been strong on the Windows OS platform, but is also seeing traction with Android. We note that share for both operating systems is expected to increase with Android accounting for more than half of the market. While WinRT has been a disappointment to date, we still expect WinOS share to grow to 16% of the market by 2016. We believe Intel tablet processors could have a TAM opportunity amounting to twothirds of the market [...] Design wins at Samsung and Asus are utilizing Intel’s current generation tablet processor (Clover Trail). We expect Intel will realize increased success as it rolls out its next-generation processor (Bay Trail) in 4Q. Bay Trail will feature design improvements including a faster processor, better graphics, and improved power efficiency. We believe the improved specs will benefit Intel."" Sterne Agee: ""We believe there is something in INTC for everybody. For the bulls, it is new product ramps at advanced nodes that close the power gap with ARM and significantly improve the chances of end-market success. For Bears it is that the core PC market which is still ~60%+ of revenues continues to be sluggish, Capex requirements for ROI continue to be high, and the success of Silvermont might hasten the decline of PCs and NBs."" (More on next post)

Topic.Title: Analysts on Intel: Lazard ponders tablet upside, Sterne Agee ponders cannibalization

Message.Msg: Part 2 : Sterne Agee ponders cannibalization of Intel products ""Near-term cannibalization concerns – The very significant power-performance improvement for INTC in tablets might be a challenge if they start to cannibalize the NB market – almost robbing Peter to pay Paul. We believe it also adds uncertainty to the 4Q Win8.1 PC-Tablet mix for OEMs-ODMs. The Handset/Tablet market inherently has shorter product cycles, more product SKUs, more competition and lower margins than the oligopolistic PC market with INTC’s dominance. But in the near term we believe INTC can mitigate the downside with new ramps and improving GMs with utilization. For INTC also, the attendant top-line increase from a tablet upside is much lower than the top-line upside from a Win8 NB pickup. We should note that IDC expects the tablet market to grow at a ~35% CAGR with the near-term PC market flattish. Longer-term unless INTC changes its business model to focus on cash flow or earnings generated, we believe GM and profitability in the lower ASP market might be a potential headwind.""

Message.Title: Computex 2013 wrap-up: a glimpse of future tech
Message.Msg: PCMag editor writes about 4 major thoughts he was left with upon conclusion of Computex 2013. Below are 2 sections relevant to NVIIDA, but the full article can be accessed via the link below: pcmagDOTcom/article2/0,2817,2419981,00.asp ""Dual- and Triple-Function Devices Last year's hybrid tablets were only the beginning. While Intel's new Haswell CPUs will definitely contribute to a growing number of PCs in more mobile, versatile form factors, Intel isn't the only company to see the writing on the wall. Nvidia is poised to put its Tegra 4 processors into everything from phones and tablets to gaming devices and laptops, further erasing the line between dedicated PCs and other tech devices. PC makers like Asus are pushing the design envelope to deliver dual- and even triple-function devices, and all signs point to this trend continuing strong."" Gaming (we are talking about PC gaming here, not console gaming) ""Finally, even with rapid evolution across the board, PC sales – the desktop and laptop kind – have flattened in many areas, yet one category has defied the trend consistently: Gaming. PC Gamers demand top performance, and are willing to pay for the latest and greatest in the pursuit of victory. As PC gaming has gotten bigger, the effort by manufacturers to attract gamers has expanded to nearly every category in the tech world. Gaming components, systems, and peripherals were out in full force in Taiwan, and many vendors courted the gaming set with appearances by professional gamers, contests for competitive overclockers, and large gaming displays. Aside from the ubiquitous booth babes, the show floor at Computex also frequently saw crowds gathered around elaborate case mods and liquid nitrogen cooling demos."" _____ The above paragraphs further confirms how well NVIDIA is positioned for the future!

Message.Title: When Intel figures out the GPU puzzle look for them to enter the discrete GPU biz
Message.Msg: You'll know Intel thinks it has figured out this whole GPU thing when they try a run at the discrete GPU business. They copied everything else AMD has done including: On-Board Memeroy Controller, x86_64 Bit extensions, Multi-Core x86 CPUs, the 1st GHz Processor and CPU+GPU Fusion Intel wants to be smart like AMD instead of just a muscle bound bully. When Intel gets its GPU legs look for them to make a run at the discrete GPU business. You know Intel wants some of that Telsa money seeing it attached to its x86 systems. You know Intel is tired of pitching Apple and then have Nvidia or AMD follow up with the GPU sale. When Intel announces their first discrete GPU what will Nvidia do after they stop laughing? This iGPU stuff is just practice for Intel. Its coming because Intel thinks if AMD can do it then so can they. IMHO of course

Topic.Title: NVIDIA Shield Australian Hands-On: The Best Portable Gaming Console You Can't Buy

Message.Msg: I am not concerned about pre-order numbers at all. It they are good, rejoice; if not, I wouldn't be disappointed either - I said this before. Very few people, especially gamers - would buy a first-generation, revolutionary product from a vendor which has never marked end-devices before. It's just common sense that most of them would want to want till they have a first-hand experience with it. I stopped by a GameStop mega store in Manhattan last weeiend and inquired about the Shield pre-order situation, the manager said that it would be very unusual if there was a robust pre-order - it's different from selling a new ipad or iphone when the customers basis had been firmed established.
